content:
The "Cut, Cap, and Balance Act of 2015" is also known as the "Cut" Act. It modifies the Congressional Budget Act by adding spending limits. The "Cut, Cap, and Balance Act of 2015" sets spending limits for fiscal year 2016 to prevent exceeding specified budget authority and outlays. Adjustments can be made for bills related to the global war on terrorism. The "Cut, Cap, and Balance Act of 2015" sets spending limits for fiscal year 2016 at $2,832,215,000,000 in new budget authority and $2,884,442,000,000 in outlays. Adjustments can be made for bills related to the global war on terrorism. The conference report allows the chair of the House or Senate Committee on the Budget to adjust spending limits for congressional enforcement based on new budget authority in a measure and its outlays. The House and Senate Committees on Appropriations may adjust spending limits based on new budget authority in a measure and its outlays, following which revised suballocations can be reported to carry out this subsection. The House or Senate Committee on Appropriations may adjust spending limits and report revised suballocations to carry out the subsection. If a bill designates amounts for Overseas Contingency Operations/Global War on Terrorism, allowable adjustments for fiscal year 2016 shall apply. The House or Senate Committee on Appropriations may adjust spending limits and report revised suballocations to carry out the subsection. If a bill designates amounts for Overseas Contingency Operations/Global War on Terrorism for fiscal year 2016, allowable adjustments shall not exceed $58,000,000,000 in budget authority and outlays. "SEC. 317. CERTAIN SPENDING LIMITS." The House of Representatives and the Senate cannot consider any bill that would exceed specified spending limits, except for certain exempt functions like Social Security, Medicare, Veterans Benefits, Net Interest, and Military personnel accounts. SEC. 102. STATUTORY ENFORCEMENT OF SPENDING CAPS THROUGH SEQUESTRATION. Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include a new section 318 for the enforcement of discretionary and direct spending caps. Implementation of sequesters: 
- Discretionary spending limits in section 316 will be sequestered separately.
- Direct spending enforcement under section 254 of the Balanced Budget Act. The sequestration for direct spending shall be implemented under section 254 of the Balanced Budget Act, excluding certain payments for military personnel, TRICARE, Medicare, military retirement, Social Security, and veterans. Payments for military personnel, TRICARE for Life, Medicare, military retirement, Social Security, veterans, net interest, and discretionary appropriations are exempt from the sequestration under this section. Presidential Order may be modified after the Director of the Office of Management and Budget issues a sequestration report. Payments for military personnel, TRICARE for Life, Medicare, military retirement, Social Security, veterans, net interest, and discretionary appropriations are exempt from sequestration. The Presidential Order can be modified after the Director of the Office of Management and Budget issues a sequestration report. Section 258A of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 applies to bills or joint resolutions in the House and Senate that aim to override a sequestration order, ensuring they achieve the same budget reductions. It is not allowed to consider a bill that alters a sequestration order in the House or Senate. Section 258A of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 prohibits bills or joint resolutions in the House and Senate from altering a sequestration order unless they achieve the same budget reductions. SEC. 201. LIMIT ON TOTAL SPENDING. The text chunk discusses amendments to definitions and caps related to fiscal matters in government legislation. It includes changes to the definition of GDP and the addition of new caps in the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. "SEC. 319. ENFORCING GDP OUTLAY LIMITS." The term 'GDP outlay limit' refers to an amount calculated by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget based on projected GDP for each fiscal year, with specific percentages set for fiscal years 2016 to 2022. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget shall establish specific percentages for fiscal years 2017 to 2025, with the GDP outlay limit determined based on projected GDP for each fiscal year. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will set 18 percent for fiscal years 2022 to 2025 as the GDP outlay limit in the President's budget. Total federal outlays will include all on-budget and off-budget expenditures. Sequestration to enforce this section will follow the guidelines of the Balanced Budget Act. The President's budget sets the GDP outlay limit for the budget year. Total federal outlays include all on-budget and off-budget expenditures. Sequestration to enforce this section will be implemented according to the Balanced Budget Act. Exempt programs under this section do not include military personnel accounts, TRICARE for Life, Medicare, military retirement, and Social Security. The Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 exempts certain programs from sequestration, including military personnel accounts, TRICARE for Life, Medicare, military retirement, Social Security, veterans, and net interest payments. SEC. 320. ENFORCEMENT PROCEDURES under the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 includes new enforcement measures. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include new enforcement procedures that prevent exceeding current GDP outlay limits. TITLE III--BALANCE

Sec. 301. Requirement for a balanced budget amendment to be submitted to states. New enforcement procedures are included in the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to prevent exceeding current GDP outlay limits. The Secretary of the Treasury cannot use additional borrowing authority until the Archivist of the United States sends a balanced budget amendment to the States. The amendment must limit total outlays, set a spending cap as a percentage of GDP, and require a \2/3\ vote for tax increases. It is not allowed in Congress to consider any bill or joint resolution that does not comply with these requirements. The amendment described in subsection (a) sets a spending cap as a percentage of GDP and requires a \2/3\ vote for tax increases. It is not permitted in Congress to consider any bill that would grant the Secretary of the Treasury additional borrowing authority until the Archivist of the United States transmits the amendment to the States.
